title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Introductions



Your name
Your affiliation
Your role
Your data cleaning experience
Your experience with R





Image from Unsplash

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
3 Phases of Data



So, before we begin, I want to clarify what we will be talking about today. So in terms of data, there are typically 3 phases.
First, there is raw data. And I am defining raw data as data that comes directly from a source. - That source could be original data

What makes it raw, no transformations
You simply downloaded
And the thing about this raw data is that it usually is messy AND it usually (in the world of education research) contains some identifying information. And we often can‚Äôt share this outside of our research team.

Next, we have the clean data. And this is the data that we will be talking about today.

This is the data we typically share
This data is still in its true, raw form, but has been de-identified and minimally altered to allow the data to be correctly interpreted.
entire study sample (no outliers have been removed), all missing data is still labelled as missing (no imputation is done), and no analysis-specific variables are calculated.

Last, we have all of these analytic datasets.

These are datasets that are created from the general clean dataset and contain further manipulations that are done for a specific analysis
These datasets will typically also be publicly shared in a repository
But these datasets are analysis specific and are not going to be part of the data cleaning process we are discussing today.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
A Sampling of Open Datasets








So in preparation for this workshop, I went through several public repositories and found a sampling of shared datasets. Let me show you some of them.
What do you notice when you look at these different datasets?
There is no real consistency in how data is structured, variables are named, or how information is coded. And this is a problem because it makes reuse of this data very difficult.
Data don‚Äôt necessarily have to be identically formatted. Different variable naming conventions can be used, different coding schemes can be used. But there are several data quality standards that all data should adhere to in order to allow data to be interpretable and usable, and that is what we are going to talk about today.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Learning Objectives


Understand how to assess a data set for 7 data quality indicators



Be able to review a data set and apply a list of standardized data cleaning steps as needed



Feel comfortable using R code to clean a data set using our standardized steps



Understand types of documentation that should be shared alongside data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
The Data are Ready


Has anyone here ever had someone give them a dataset that they‚Äôve said is good to go, but then you open the data and it looks something like this? Just a mess.
I feel like this happens to me on a weekly basis.
So today we are going to review a standard set of data quality indicators that we can use to determine if a dataset is really ready to be shared or not.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
7 Data Quality Indicators




Analyzable
Interpretable
Complete
Valid
Accurate
Consistent
De-identified





Taming the Data Beast, by Allison Horst

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable

Data should make a rectangle of rows and columns

The first row, and only the first row, is your variable names
The remaining data should be made up of values in cells
At least one column uniquely defines the rows in the data (e.g., unique identifier)




So first and foremost, data needs to make a rectangle. This rectangle shape is how machines read data.

short representation of the information contained in a column.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable

Column values are analyzable

Information is explicit




Another rule of analyzable data is that information is explicit, not implicit. This means unless data is actually missing, there should be no blanks in your data. They should be filled with the applicable values.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable



Another example of data that is not explicit is when color coding is used. Here, color coding is used to indicate study treatment groups. However, machines cannot interpret color codes. This information needs to be defined in a variable with values assigned for each group.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Analyzable

Only one piece of information is collected per variable



And then last, for data to be analyzable, you should only collect one piece of information per variable. In this example, a rate variable has been included the data where the numerator is the number of incidents and the denominator is the total number of students in the school. But it is difficult to work with combined information. It‚Äôs much better to separate those pieces of information into their own variables and then you can aggregate information as needed.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúanalyzable‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Data does not make a rectangle
Color coding used to convey information
More than one piece of information in a variable
Blank values implied to be 0 for Q4 variables

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Interpretable



Variable names should be machine-readable

Unique
No spaces or special characters except _

This includes no . or -

Not begin with a number
Character limit of 32

Variable names should be human-readable

Meaningful (gender instead of Q1)
Consistently formatted (capitalization and delimiters)
Consistent order of information

wave_responder_scale# (w1_t_mast1)







In that case, by Allison Horst






First interpretable applies to your variable names
Even dashes are not allowed because R reads them as minus signs
While periods are allowed in R, they aren‚Äôt in other languages like Stata so it‚Äôs best to avoid them.
Most statistical programs are case sensitive so if you are inconsistent with things like delimiters and capitalization, it just makes it so much more difficult to work with your data.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Interpretable

When publicly sharing data, it is recommended to share data in at least one non-proprietary format (e.g., CSV)

But if you would also like to share a copy in a commonly used format such as SPSS, SAS, or Stata, consider adding embedded metadata (i.e., variable label and value labels)





But interpretable can also apply to other formatting
Because that can really help with interpretation. Rather than having to flip back and forth to the data dictionary to see what codes mean or what a variable represents, the information lives within the dataset and can be accessed as needed.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúinterpretable‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Spaces and special characters used in variable names
Some variable names are unclear
Inconsistent use of capitalization

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Complete

Cases

The number of rows in your dataset should total to your sample N

No missing cases
No duplicate cases (i.e., no unique identifier)


Variables

The number of columns in your dataset should total to what you planned to have

No missing variables

No unexpected missing data

If you collected the data, it should exist in the dataset

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Complete
Tracking Database





Data Dictionary






Two documents that can be helpful for verifying if you have complete data are a participant tracking database and a data dictionary.
A participant tracking database is a spreadsheet or database where a project coordinator tracks what is collected in a study for each participant. Depending on your role in the study, you may or may not have access to this type of database. If you do not, you are just going to have to trust that you have been given a dataset that includes the entire sample.
A data dictionary is something you hopefully always have access to though and this should list out exactly what variables exist in a dataset and what those variables represent.
Both of these documents are excellent resources for determining if you have a complete dataset.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00




Here we don‚Äôt have access to a tracking database or a data dictionary but there is still something we can catch in this dataset without those documents.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

The data contain a duplicate ID (104)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Valid

Variables conform to the planned constraints

Planned variable types (e.g., numeric, character, date)
Allowable variable values and ranges (e.g., 1-5)
Item-level missingness aligns with variable universe rules and skip patterns

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Valid


Again, the data dictionary is going to be a really important document in determining if data is valid because the dicionary defines all of the constraints that need to be checked.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúvalid‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00




Again we don‚Äôt have a data dictionary for this example‚Ä¶

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

AGE/YR does not adhere to our planned variable type
Values in Score fall out of our expected range

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Accurate

Information should be accurate based on any implicit knowledge you have

For instance, values should not exist for a school where you know that data was not collected that wave

Accurate within and across sources

A date of birth collected from school records should match the date of birth provided by the student
If a student is in 2nd grade, they should be associated with a second grade teacher



So accuracy can be a tough thing to judge, but depending on your level of involvement in the study, you may have some implicit knowledge you can use to judge accuracy.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúaccurate‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00




So in this case we don‚Äôt have any implicit knowledge, but by comparing pieces of information within the dataset, what data quality issues do you see for the accurate indicator here?

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

ID 105 has conflicting information for TEACHING LEVEL and SCHOOL

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Consistent

Variable values are consistently measured, formatted, or categorized within a column
Variables are consistently measured across collections of the same form



And the reason that this consistency matters is that a computer doesn‚Äôt know that three different spellings of yes are all still yes. It will think these are 3 different things.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúconsistent‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Values for GENDER are not consistently categorized

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identified


In the world of education research we are often working with human subjects and we often promise those subjects that their identifying information will remain private
Direct identifiers are unique to an individual and can be used alone to identify a participant.
Indirect identifiers however are not necessarily unique to a particular individual, but if combined with other information they could be used to identify a participant.

age + gender + education level
50 + female + PhD
it‚Äôs possible that someone could use that information to identify someone in a dataset

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identified

Direct identifiers are removed

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identified

Open-ended questions

These variables may contain information that can directly or indirectly identify individuals

Outliers

If someone has extreme values for a variable, it may be easier to identify that individual

Small cell sizes

NCES Standard 4-2-10, suggests that all categories have at least 3 cases to minimize risk

Combinations of variables, or crosstabs, can also create small cell-sizes

race + gender + grade level



üö® Consider this in the context of risk

Math assessment may be low risk while a survey on substance use is higher risk


But there is more you need to check for.
You also need to consider all of this in the context of risk. So if you are collecting information that is fairly innocuous (like maybe it‚Äôs a math assessment), the risk of harm if your re-identified is pretty low. If you are collecting information like on substance use, the risk is higher because that information could impact your career, relationships, and so forth.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

What data quality issues do you detect for the ‚Äúde-identified‚Äù indicator?




‚àí+
01:00




This is a very small dataset so don‚Äôt worry about indirect identifiers right now. Focus more on direct identifiers

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Solution

Replace School Name with an unique ID
Review outliers and combination of demographics to see if other alterations are necessary

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Biggest Advice
The number one way to reduce data errors is to make a plan before you collect data

Correct data at the source




Plan the variables you want to collect




Build your data collection/entry tools in a way that follows your plan




Test your data tools before collecting/entering data




Check your data often during data collection/entry


So before we move on to how to clean data for the purposes of data sharing, I want to point out one really important thing. And that is, if you are collecting your own original data
Doing this ensures not only that you have much less data cleaning to do in the end, but it also prevents you from potentially losing data or having to recollect bad data. So it‚Äôs 100% worth the time and effort to spend time planning for quality data collection in the beginning if you can.
But of course, we are not always in charge of data collection and we just have to deal with the data we are given and so are going to talk about this in the next sections.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Data Cleaning

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Standard Data Cleaning Checklist


 Import the raw data
 Review the raw data
 Find missing data
 Adjust the sample
 De-identify data
 Drop irrelevant columns
 Split columns
 Rename variables
 Normalize variables
 Standardize variables

 Update variable types
 Recode variables
 Construct new variables
 Add missing values
 Add metadata
 Validate data
 Join data
 Reshape data
 Save clean data



However, to produce datasets that consistently meet the data quality criteria we just reviewed, it can be helpful to follow a standardized checklist of data cleaning steps. These steps, although they are really general here, once you tailor them to your specific data source they can help you produce a dataset that meets our data quality standards.
As you use this checklist to clean your specific datasaet you use the steps that are relevant to your data and remove the steps that are not relevant.
The order of these steps are fluid. With the exception of the first two on the list, you can move them around in whatever order makes sense for your specific dataset.
We are going to take some time to review each step on this list with the exception of the ones in blue. Those require more time to cover than we have today, so instead I have linked to more information here for you to review in your own time.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Import raw data


Importing your raw data will always be number one of course, and the most important rule here is to never make any manual edits directly in the raw data file. Your raw data file is your single source of truth for that data source. If you make errors in your data cleaning process, you should always be able to go back to the untouched raw data to start over again if you need to.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Review data


Reviewing your data should always be step number two. It‚Äôs important that you know exactly what is happening in your data before moving forward in the cleaning process.
If you have access to those documents we discussed earlier, participant tracking database and a data dictionary, now is the time to use them.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Find missing data


If you find that any data is missing in your review process (missing cases/missing variables) you‚Äôll want to retrieve that missing data before moving forward in the cleaning process
Start back at step 1

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Adjust the sample


This means removing anyone who should not be in the dataset - maybe they didn‚Äôt consent to be in the study
It also means taking care of any duplicates in your data
The first thing you‚Äôll want to do before removing duplicates is determine if it is a true duplicate, not just an error in the data
Then removing any true duplicates based on your duplicate removal rule
It‚Äôs really important that these kinds of decisions rules are documented for future data users. And we‚Äôll talk more about where to document these kinds of things later.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: De-identify data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: De-identify data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identify data




Source
Resource




Alena Filip
Table 2 provides pros and cons of various de-identification methods


J-PAL
Table 3 provides a list of direct and indirect identifiers and recommended removal methods


Schatschneider, et.al
Deidentifying Data Guide





Redaction

Eliminate the entire variable from the data

Suppression

Remove data in a particular cell or row (In this example, age 67 was an outlier so I suppressed that cell value and replaced it with -98 which I‚Äôve coded as suppressed).

Generalization

Reduce precision in the data (In this example here, I‚Äôve binned my age rages so they are less precise)

Truncation

Restricting upper and lower ranges to mask outliers


There are many, even more sophisticated ways, to de-identify data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Drop irrelevant columns

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Split columns

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Rename variables

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Normalize variables

Compare the variable types in your raw data to the types you expected in your data dictionary.

Do they align? If not, what needs to be done so that they do




I realize this is unconventional terminology to use, but here I am using the term normalize to talk about returning variables to their normal or expected state.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Standardize variables

Are columns consistently measured, categorized, and formatted according to your data dictionary?

If not, what needs to be done so that they are




Here I am using the term standardize to convey the process of checking for consistency

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Update variable types


Character to Numeric, Numeric to Date, And so forth

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Recode variables



This includes recoding your categorical numeric values to match your data dictionary values
But it also includes any planned coding, such as reverse coding a variable
As well as recoding any implicit values to their explicit values

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Construct additional variables



This is not the time to construct analysis-specific variables. This is the time to create or calculate variables that should always be a part of the core study dataset.
This could be things like grouping variables (treatment, cohort, site)
It could be time component variables (year, wave)
It could be additional unique identifiers that you need to add for linking purposes (like adding a school ID to a teacher file)
Or it could be measure composite or summary scores that you want included in the core dataset
Any other variables you want added to the core sharing dataset
Some of these variables will be calculated, others may be merged in from other sources

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Add missing values

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Data validation



















You should absolutely be checking your transformations throughout your cleaning process, but then, before exporting your data you should do one final review to make sure you haven‚Äôt missed anything.
Here are several examples where various researchers did not have data validation as part of their data cleaning process and found out much later on that their data contained errors. And so we want to try to prevent this scenario by catching any errors now, rather than later.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Data validation



Complete

Check for missing/duplicate cases

Check Ns by groups for completeness

Check for missing/too many columns

Valid and consistent

Check for unallowed categories/values out of range

Check ranges by groups

Check for invalid, non-unique, or missing study IDs
Check for incorrect variable types/formats
Check missing value patterns




Accurate

Agreement across variables

De-identified

All direct identifiers are removed
All indirect identifiers managed as needed

Interpretable

Variables correctly named





Use your data quality indicator list as a guide when doing your final data review

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Data validation



Documentation errors

Fix in documentation

Data cleaning errors

Fix in your cleaning process

Data entry/export process errors

Fix at the source and export new raw file

True values that are inaccurate, uninterpretable, or outside of a valid range

Leave the data as is (document the issue)
Recode those values to designated error code
Create data quality indicators
Choose one source of truth for inconsistent values
Use logical/deductive editing











What‚Äôs most important is that you document your decisions for future users

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: Export data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Export data
When you export your files, it‚Äôs important to name them consistently and clearly.

Follow rules similar to our variable naming rules

Machine readable (except now - is allowed)
Human readable

A user should be able to understand the contents of the file without opening it




Which gives you a better idea of what is in the file? ü§î

‚ÄúProject X Full Data.csv‚Äù
‚Äúprojectx_wave1_stu_svy_clean.csv‚Äù

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Creating a data cleaning plan


Ultimately what I like to do in a cleaning process is pull out my checklist, import and review my data, and then plan out the steps that are needed to clean my specific dataset

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text: BREAK!

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
BREAK!



‚àí+
15:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Objects


If you want to save the work you do, you need to save it to an object that lives in your environment

Objects should follow the same naming rules we discussed earlier

If you simply want to view the results, you don‚Äôt need to save values into an object





age <- c(12, 10, 8)

age <- age + 1



mean(age)

[1] 11

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Objects



Data Frame (Tibble)

Two dimensional structure


df <- data.frame(id = c(10, 20),
                 age = c(12, 8))

df

  id age
1 10  12
2 20   8



Vector

Consists of one or more elements all of the same type


id <- c(10, 20)

id

[1] 10 20



Common vector types (class)

character, numeric, date, logical

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Functions



Anatomy of a function

function_name(argument1, argument2, argument3, ‚Ä¶)

the first argument is usually an object

You can view arguments by typing ?functionname in your console

Arguments usually have defaults

For example mean(x, trim, na.rm)

trim = 0
na.rm = FALSE


R has many built in (base) functions


  



Function
Task




View()
View object


str()
Display internal structure of an object


c()
Combine elements


class()
Check the class/type of an object






If you like the defaults, do nothing. You don‚Äôt have to type out the arguments. If you want to change the default, you need to type out the arguments.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Packages

We can also use functions that live in packages that we can install onto our computer
Once installed, there are two ways to call packages

You may see both methods used in these slides





Using library()

library(dplyr)

select(df, var1, var2) 


Using Namespacing package::function()

# library(dplyr) not needed

dplyr::select(df, var1, var2) 




Foundational

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Tidyverse

An opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science
All packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Tidyverse

Selecting test_score and grade_level from our data frame named sch_data



Tidy Evaluation


select(df, test_score, 
       grade_level)

# A tibble: 3 x 2
  test_score grade_level
       <dbl>       <dbl>
1        350           3
2        380           4
3        290           5



Base R


df[ , c("test_score", 
              "grade_level")]

# A tibble: 3 x 2
  test_score grade_level
       <dbl>       <dbl>
1        350           3
2        380           4
3        290           5

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Pipes

2014+ magrittr pipe %>%
2021+ (R \(\geq\) 4.1.0) native R pipe |>


Isabella Vel√°squez‚Äôs blog post Understanding the native R pipe |> (2022)






sch_data <- select(sch_data, id, 
                    test_score)

sch_data <- filter(sch_data, 
                    test_score > 300)



sch_data <- sch_data |>
  select(id, test_score) |>
  filter(test_score > 300)






To turn on the native pipe:
Tools ‚Üí Global Options ‚Üí Code ‚Üí Editing ‚Üí Use Native Pipe Operator

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Operators


Comparison operators

== equal to
!= not equal to
< less than
> greater than
%in% value is present within


df |>
  filter(city %in% c("boston","philly"))


Assignment operators

<- Assign value to an object
= Assign value to an object


df <- df |>
  mutate(year = "2024")

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Scenario
Take 5 minutes to open and look at our data file.

Log in to Posit Cloud and navigate to our project

https://posit.cloud/content/7872027

Open the data folder and open ‚Äúsample_tch_svy_raw.xlsx‚Äù

Notice that the ‚Äúlabels‚Äù tab has some basic information about the variables






‚àí+
05:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Import our data

Common data importing functions

read_csv(), read_delim() from the readr package
read_excel() from the readxl package
read_sav(), read_sas(), read_dta() from the haven package
Learn more about importing multiple files at once here



Which function should we use to read in our sample data?ü§î

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Import our file



read_excel() has several arguments.

path

Name of the file, plus folder names as needed
‚Äúdata/w1_stu_obs_raw.xlsx‚Äù

sheet = NULL
col_names = TRUE
na = ‚Äú‚Äù
skip = 0

Type ?read_excel() in your console to see more arguments

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 3 minutes to import the data.


Open ‚Äúexercises.Rmd‚Äù in our Posit Cloud project.
Navigate to exercise 1.
Update the code and run the code to read in the data using the green arrow.
Run the code chunk to view the data.

If you get stuck, you can open ‚Äúsolutions.Rmd‚Äù



‚àí+
03:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Review our data




How many rows?

In this hypothetical situation, we assume we are not missing any cases
However, there may be duplicates

How many columns?

Compare to our data dictionary

What are the variable values and ranges?

Compare to our data dictionary

How much missing data do we have?


There are several functions we can use to explore data

dplyr::glimpse()
skimr::skim()
base::summary()
summarytools::dfSummary()
Hmisc::describe()

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 5 minutes to review our data.

Navigate to exercise 2.
Run the code.

Write down any potential issues you see in the data.

Open ‚Äúsample_tch_svy_data_dictionary.xlsx‚Äù in the docs folder.

What issues do you see when you compare the data to our data dictionary?

Review ‚Äúsample_tch_svy_cleaning-plan.txt‚Äù in the docs folder.

How does it compare to the issues you wrote down?





‚àí+
05:00




So we are going to follow this data cleaning plan for the rest of this section

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Adjust the sample

There are two key functions we can use to both identify and remove duplicates in our data


janitor::get_dupes()

Tells you which rows contain duplicate unique identifiers, if any




dplyr::distinct()

Keeps the first instance of a duplicate unique identifier



So the next step in our checklist is to adjust the sample And we found some duplicates in our sample

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Adjust the sample

Check for duplicatesRemove duplicatesRemove duplicates



df |>
  get_dupes(id_vars)


Replace id_vars with your unique identifier
If you have more than one variable that uniquely identifies rows, use c(first_name, last_name)




df |>
  distinct(id_vars, 
           .keep_all = TRUE)


Replace id_vars with your unique identifier/s
Always add the argument .keep_all = TRUE
But remember, this always keeps the first instance of your duplicate

This may not always be want you want





df |>
  arrange(date) |>
  distinct(id_vars, 
           .keep_all = TRUE)


Consider arranging your data first, before removing duplicates
Replace date with any variable that you want to arrange your data by

The default is to sort values in ascending order

If you want descending order `arrange(desc(date))

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 5 minutes to check for and remove duplicates.

Navigate to exercise 3.
Run the code to check for duplicates.

Which tch_id is duplicated?

Run the code to remove our duplicates.

Our documented rule is that if both surveys are complete, keep the most recently completed row.

Run a check to make sure duplicates are removed.
Run the code to confirm that we kept the most recent submission of the duplicate survey (‚Äú2024-04-02‚Äù).




‚àí+
05:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identify data

The functions used here will depend on what is required.

Examples of functions you might use:

dplyr::select() to drop variables
dplyr::case_when() or dplyr::recode() to collapse categories/recode values
dplyr::*_join() to merge in study unique IDs
stringr::str_remove_all() or stringr::str_replace_all() to redact character values

For our sample data we are going to use the following.

dplyr::case_when() to recategorize names into our unique study ID values and
dplyr::select() to drop identifying variables

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
De-identify data

Recategorize valuesRecategorize valuesSelect variables



df |>
  dplyr::mutate(new_var_name =
                  case_when(
                    var_name == old_value1 ~ new_value1,
                    var_name == old_value2 ~ new_value2
                  ))


To learn more about setting default values for case_when(), type ?case_when in your console
Note that there is a new function, case_match(), that is worth looking in to. It reduces repetition in the syntax.





My data frame that I want to de-identify


     name score
1    emma    22
2 brandon    40




df |>
  mutate(id = 
           case_when(
             name == "emma" ~ 300,
             name == "brandon" ~ 301
           ))

     name score  id
1    emma    22 300
2 brandon    40 301








To select variables of interest

df |>
  select(varname1, varname2, varname3)


df |>
  select(varname1:varname3)

Using tidyselection helpers ::: {.cell}
df |>
  select(starts_with("grade"))



To drop variables I add -

df |>
  select(-varname1)


df |>
  select(-varname1:varname3)


df |>
  select(-c(varname1, varname4))


df |>
  select(-starts_with("name"))





:::

text:
Exercise

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Rename variables
Two functions we can use to rename variables

dplyr::rename()

Commonly used to rename just a few variables

purrr::set_names()

Used to rename all of our variables
Variables must be in the exact right order





Rename just a few variables

df |>
  rename(new_name = old_name)


Rename all variables

df |>
  set_names(c("name1", "name2", "name3"))

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 3 minutes to rename variables

Navigate to exercise 3.
Review the current variable names.
Rename variables according to our data dictionary.
Check variable names again to make sure the renaming worked.




‚àí+
03:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Normalize variables
There are several functions that can help us remove unexpected values from our variables.
Some examples of those include:

stringr::str_remove_all()
stringr::str_replace_all()
readr::parse_number()


Say this is our data


# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income 
  <dbl> <chr>  
1     1 $32,000
2     2 120000 
3     3 $45,000

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Normalize variables



Remove character values with stringr::str_remove_all()

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(income = 
                  str_remove_all(income, "\\$|,"))

# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income
  <dbl> <chr> 
1     1 32000 
2     2 120000
3     3 45000 



Notice that our variable is still character type


Remove character values with readr::parse_number()

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(income = 
                  parse_number(income))

# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income
  <dbl>  <dbl>
1     1  32000
2     2 120000
3     3  45000



Notice that parse_number() converts our variable to numeric type

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 3 minutes to normalize our tch_yrs variable

Navigate to exercise 6.
Review the current values for tch_yrs.
Remove all non-numeric values from this variable.
Review the new values in tch_yrs.




‚àí+
03:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Update variable type
Depending on what is needed, there are several functions we can use to change variable types.

Some examples include:

as.numeric()
as.character()
as.Date()
Several functions in the lubridate package to assist with converting dates
janitor::excel_numeric_to_date() can be very helpful at times

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Update variable type
It‚Äôs important to normalize variables before converting types (especially when converting from character to numeric)



Our data without normalizing

df

# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income 
  <dbl> <chr>  
1     1 $32,000
2     2 120000 
3     3 $45,000



When we try to convert income to numeric‚Ä¶.

df |>
  dplyr::mutate(income = 
                  as.numeric(income))

Warning in mask$eval_all_mutate(quo): NAs introduced by coercion


# A tibble: 3 x 2
     id income
  <dbl>  <dbl>
1     1     NA
2     2 120000
3     3     NA


We end up converting several values to NA (notice our warning)

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 3 minutes to convert tch_yrs to numeric

Navigate to exercise 7.
Review the current variable type for tch_yrs.
Convert the variable to numeric.
Review the new variable type for tch_yrs.




‚àí+
03:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Recode variables
Common functions for recoding values are

dplyr::case_when()
dplyr::recode()
tidyr::replace_na()





df |>
  mutate(newvar = 
           recode(oldvar,
                  `oldvalue` = newvalue))



df |> 
  mutate(newvar = 
           replace_na(oldvar, 
                      replace = 0))

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Recode variables

dplyr::across() allows you to apply the same transformation across multiple columns - This can be used in case_when(), recode(), or replace_na()


df |>
  mutate(across(var1:var3, 
                  ~ replace_na(., replace = 0)))

This will save over existing variables. - If you don‚Äôt want to save over the existing variables, you can add the argument .names which lives in the dplyr::across() function. This creates new variables with new names.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Exercise

Take 5 minutes to recode variables

Navigate to exercise 8.
Recode the blank values for the grade variables.

Check to see if the recoding worked.

Recode the mathanx variable.

Check to see that the recoding worked.





‚àí+
05:00

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Construct new variables

The most important function for constructing new variables is dplyr::mutate()
From there, other functions may be required. For today, we are going to use rowSums() which allows us to create sum scores for each row




The default is to not calculate a sum if there are any NA values

df |>
  mutate(newvar = rowSums(
    across(var1:var3)))


If you want to calculate a sum even if there are NA values, add na.rm = TRUE

df |>
  mutate(newvar = rowSums(
    across(var1:var3), na.rm = TRUE))

text:
Validate data



Create tables of information

dplyr::count(), janitor::tabyl()

Create graphs

ggplot2

Calculate summary statistics

All of the functions from ‚ÄúReview the data‚Äù section

Create codebooks

codebookr, memisc, sjPlot

Creating tests that pass/fail based on a set of criteria

pointblank, validate, assertr, dataquieR












There are many ways to validate data based on data quality criteria
You most likely want to do a combination of these things in your validation process

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Export data
Similar to importing data, we have many options for exporting our data depending on the format we want to export to.

openxlsx::write.xlsx()
haven::write_sav(), haven::write_dta(), haven::write_sas()
readr::write_csv()

x

The object we are exporting

file

The name of the new file plus any folders where you want the file to live

na = ‚ÄúNA‚Äù



write_csv(df, file = "data/w1_stu_obs_clean.csv", na = "")

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Coding best practices



Use a coding template
Follow a coding style guide

The tidyverse style guide

Use relative file paths

‚ùå ‚ÄúC:/Users/Crystal/Desktop/project/data/raw_file.csv‚Äù
‚úîÔ∏è ‚Äúdata/raw_file.csv‚Äù

Write all cleaning steps in code
Comment every step in your code
Check all of your work throughout
If possible, have someone else review your code










You may have noticed that throughout these exercises, I always performed a check to make sure that the transformation worked as expected

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Versioning

Version your code (‚Äúsample_tch_svy_cleaning_v01.R‚Äù)
Version your files (‚Äúsample_tch_svy_clean_v01.csv‚Äù)
Make notes in a changelog.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Types of documentation




Project-level documentation

Project summary document

Data-level documentation

README
Cleaning code/Data cleaning plan

Variable-level documentation

Data dictionary OR
Codebook

Repository Metadata




‚úîÔ∏è Allows your data to be correctly interpreted and used

‚úîÔ∏è Allows your work to be reproducible

‚úîÔ∏è Allows your work to be findable



And some documentation, like repository metadata, allows your data to be findable

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Project-level documentation



Funding source
Overview of study
Setting and sample
Project timeline
Measures used
Overview of study procedures

Recruitment, consent, data collection

Data preparation and processing

Data quality monitoring, de-identification procedures, decision rules

Appendices

Copies of instruments, consort diagrams











This would be where you could document your decision rules for things dropping duplicates

text:
Data-level documentation


README






Data Cleaning Plan

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Variable-level documentation


Data dictionary






Codebook

text:
Repository Metadata

title: Pre-work
text:
A portion of this workshop will be conducted in the Posit Cloud environment. Posit Cloud allows us all to work in the exact same environment with the same version of R, R packages, and directory of files. .
Please create a login to the Posit Cloud instance of this workshop here:
https://posit.cloud/content/7872027
Alternative
If you are struggling using Posit Cloud, you can download the materials locally on your machine.
Note that the presenter will NOT be able to help you with local computer problems during the workshop. To do this you will need the following to do the following prior to the workshop:
pkgs <- c("tidyverse", "readxl", "summarytools", "janitor", "pointblank")

install.packages(pkgs)
# install.packages("usethis")
usethis::use_course(
    "https://github.com/Cghlewis/ncme-data-cleaning-workshop/raw/main/exercises/exercises.zip",
    destdir = "___")

title: Pre-work
text:
R and RStudio
For this workshop it is assumed that you are comfortable navigating the RStudio environment and that you have some understanding of things like packages, functions, objects, file paths, and R syntax. If you need any refreshers, I recommend reviewing the following materials.

Getting Started with R

What They Forgot to Teach You About R (In particular, the ‚ÄúA holistic workflow‚Äù section)
R and Tidyverse for working with data
R Software Handbook

title: Pre-work
text:
Tidyverse
If you‚Äôre new to the {tidyverse}, here are some materials I recommend reviewing before the workshop.

R for Data Science
Tidyverse Skills for Data Science

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
NCME 2024 Workshop
üìÜ April 11, 2024 // 8:45 am - 12:45 pm EDT
üè® In Person
üìù NCME attendees can register here
üè° Workshop website

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Learning objectives

Understand how to assess a data set for 7 data quality indicators
Be able to review a data set and apply a list of standardized data cleaning steps as needed
Feel comfortable using R code to clean a data set
Understand types of documentation that should be shared alongside data

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Is this workshop for me?
This workshop is for any education researcher who could benefit from guidance on how to take a messy raw dataset and organize it into a shareable data product.
This workshop assumes you have some experience working with rectangular data, as well as a basic working knowledge of the R programming language and experience working in RStudio. This course will focus on functions in the {Tidyverse} so familiarity with that package will be helpful, but is not required.

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Further Learning

Data Management in Large-Scale Education Research book
The Basics of Data Management
Data Organization in Spreadsheets
Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Blog Post Series
Four Simple Ways to Integrate your Data Dictionary into Your Data Cleaning Process
R Data Wrangling Functions Wiki

title: Data Cleaning for Data Sharing Using R
text:
Speaker
 Crystal Lewis is an independent research data management consultant, providing recommendations, direct service, and training to education researchers and their teams across the country. She also co-organizes two community groups‚ÄîR-Ladies St.¬†Louis, an organization focused on promoting gender diversity in the R community, as well as the POWER (providing women opportunities in education research) Data Management Hub, where she facilitates peer data management support in the education research community.
